<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Amber_Room skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Amber Room</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="dablink">"The Amber Room" redirects here. For the book, see <a href="/wiki/The_Amber_Room_(novel)" title="The Amber Room (novel)">The Amber Room (novel)</a>.</div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bernsteinzimmer02.jpg" title="File:Bernsteinzimmer02.jpg">File:Bernsteinzimmer02.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">354x354px</div></div></div>
<p>The <b>Amber Room</b> (sometimes known as the <i>Amber Chamber</i>&#160;; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Language_with_name&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Language with name (page does not exist)">Template:Language with name</a> <i>Yantarnaya komnata</i>&#160;; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-de&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-de (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-de</a>) in the <a href="/wiki/Catherine_Palace" title="Catherine Palace">Catherine Palace</a> of <a href="/wiki/Tsarskoye_Selo" title="Tsarskoye Selo">Tsarskoye Selo</a> near <a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Petersburg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Saint Petersburg (page does not exist)">Saint Petersburg</a> is a complete chamber decoration of <a href="/wiki/Amber" title="Amber">amber</a> panels backed with <a href="/wiki/Gold" title="Gold">gold</a> leaf and <a href="/wiki/Mirror" title="Mirror">mirrors</a>. Created in the 18th century, it disappeared during World War II, and was recreated in 2003.
</p><p>Before it was lost, the Amber Room was sometimes dubbed the "<a href="/wiki/Eighth_Wonder_of_the_World" title="Eighth Wonder of the World">Eighth Wonder of the World</a>" due to its singular beauty. Construction of the Amber Room took place from 1701 to 1711 in <a href="/wiki/Prussia" title="Prussia">Prussia</a>. The room was designed by German baroque sculptor <a href="/wiki/Andreas_Schl%C3%BCter" title="Andreas Schlüter">Andreas Schlüter</a> and Danish amber craftsman Gottfried Wolfram in the service of the Prussian king worked on it until 1707, then work was continued by amber masters Gottfried Turau and Ernst Schacht from <a href="/wiki/Danzig" title="Danzig" class="mw-redirect">Danzig</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> The amber cabinet remained in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Berlin_City_Palace&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Berlin City Palace (page does not exist)">Berlin City Palace</a> until 1716 when it was given by Prussian king <a href="/wiki/Frederick_William_I_of_Prussia" title="Frederick William I of Prussia">Friedrich Wilhelm I</a> to his then ally, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tsar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tsar (page does not exist)">Tsar</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Peter_I_of_Russia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peter I of Russia (page does not exist)">Peter the Great</a> of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Russian_Empire&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Russian Empire (page does not exist)">Russian Empire</a>. In Russia it was expanded and after several renovations, it covered more than 55 square metres and contained over six tons of amber. It was finished in 1755 and restored in 1830. The Amber Room was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Looted_art&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Looted art (page does not exist)">looted</a> during <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> by <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a> and brought to <a href="/w/index.php?title=K%C3%B6nigsberg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Königsberg (page does not exist)">Königsberg</a>. Knowledge of its whereabouts was lost in the chaos at the end of the war.
</p><p>In 1979, efforts were undertaken to rebuild the Amber room at <a href="/wiki/Tsarskoye_Selo" title="Tsarskoye Selo">Tsarskoye Selo</a>. In 2003, after decades of work by Russian craftsmen, financed by donations from Germany, the reconstructed Amber Room was inaugurated in the Catherine Palace in <a href="/wiki/St._Petersburg" title="St. Petersburg" class="mw-redirect">St. Petersburg</a>, Russia.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#History"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">History</span></a>
<ul>

<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-3"><a href="#World_War_II_evacuation"><span class="tocnumber">1.2</span> <span class="toctext">World War II evacuation</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4"><a href="#Last_days_in_K.C3.B6nigsberg"><span class="tocnumber">1.3</span> <span class="toctext">Last days in Königsberg</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-5"><a href="#Disappearance_and_mystery"><span class="tocnumber">1.4</span> <span class="toctext">Disappearance and mystery</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-6"><a href="#Destruction_theory"><span class="tocnumber">1.5</span> <span class="toctext">Destruction theory</span></a></li>

</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-8"><a href="#Appearances_in_fiction"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Appearances in fiction</span></a></li>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-10"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-11"><a href="#Citations"><span class="tocnumber">4.1</span> <span class="toctext">Citations</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-12"><a href="#Other_sources"><span class="tocnumber">4.2</span> <span class="toctext">Other sources</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-13"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Creation">Creation</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Catherine_Palace_Amber_Room.jpg" title="File:Catherine Palace Amber Room.jpg">File:Catherine Palace Amber Room.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Section of the reconstructed Amber Room.</div></div></div>
<p>The Amber Room was made from 1701 onwards in order to be installed at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Charlottenburg_Palace&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Charlottenburg Palace (page does not exist)">Charlottenburg Palace</a>, home of <a href="/wiki/Frederick_I_of_Prussia" title="Frederick I of Prussia">Friedrich I</a>, the first king of <a href="/wiki/Prussia" title="Prussia">Prussia</a>, at the urging of his second wife, <a href="/wiki/Sophia_Charlotte_of_Hanover" title="Sophia Charlotte of Hanover">Sophie Charlotte</a>. The concept of the room and its design was by <a href="/wiki/Andreas_Schl%C3%BCter" title="Andreas Schlüter">Andreas Schlüter</a>. It was crafted by Gottfried Wolfram, master <a href="/wiki/Artisan" title="Artisan">craftsman</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Danish</a> court of King <a href="/wiki/Frederick_IV_of_Denmark" title="Frederick IV of Denmark">Frederick IV of Denmark</a>, with help from the amber masters Ernst Schacht and Gottfried Turau from <a href="/wiki/Danzig" title="Danzig" class="mw-redirect">Danzig</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although originally intended for installation at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Charlottenburg_Palace&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Charlottenburg Palace (page does not exist)">Charlottenburg Palace</a>, the complete panels were eventually installed at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Berlin_City_Palace&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Berlin City Palace (page does not exist)">Berlin City Palace</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> The Amber Room did not, however, remain at Berlin Castle for long. <a href="/wiki/Peter_the_Great" title="Peter the Great">Peter the Great</a> admired it on a visit and in 1716, <a href="/wiki/Frederick_William_I_of_Prussia" title="Frederick William I of Prussia">Friedrich Wilhelm I</a>, the first king's son, presented it to him, and with that act cemented a Prussian-Russian alliance against <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sweden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sweden (page does not exist)">Sweden</a>.
</p><p>The original Berlin design was reworked into the Amber Room in Russia in a joint effort of German and Russian craftsmen. After several other 18th century renovations, it covered more than 55 square metres and contained over <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of amber. It took over ten years to construct.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="World_War_II_evacuation">World War II evacuation</span></h3>
<p>Shortly after the beginning of the German invasion of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> in World War II (<a href="/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa" title="Operation Barbarossa">Operation Barbarossa</a>), the curators responsible for removing the art treasures in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Petersburg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Saint Petersburg (page does not exist)">Leningrad</a> tried to disassemble and remove the Amber Room. Over the years the amber had dried out and become brittle, so that when they tried to remove it, the fragile amber started to crumble. The Amber Room was therefore hidden behind mundane <a href="/wiki/Wallpaper" title="Wallpaper">wallpaper</a>, in an attempt to keep German forces from seizing it. However, the attempt to hide such a well-known piece of art failed.
</p><p>German soldiers disassembled the Amber Room within 36 hours under the supervision of two experts. On 14 October 1941, Rittmeister Graf Solms-Laubach commanded the evacuation of 27 crates to <a href="/w/index.php?title=K%C3%B6nigsberg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Königsberg (page does not exist)">Königsberg</a> in <a href="/wiki/East_Prussia" title="East Prussia">East Prussia</a>, for storage and display in the town's castle. On 13 November 1941, the newspaper <i>Königsberger Allgemeine Zeitung</i> reported on an exhibition of part of the "Bernsteinzimmer" in <a href="/w/index.php?title=K%C3%B6nigsberg_Castle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Königsberg Castle (page does not exist)">Königsberg Castle</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Last_days_in_K.C3.B6nigsberg">Last days in Königsberg</span></h3>
<p>Orders by Hitler given on 21 January and 24 January 1945 allowed the movement of possessions. From that day onwards, <a href="/wiki/Albert_Speer" title="Albert Speer">Albert Speer</a>'s administration could move culture goods of priority "I (o)". <a href="/wiki/Erich_Koch" title="Erich Koch">Erich Koch</a> was in charge in Königsberg. Eyewitnesses claimed that crates had been sighted at the railway station. They might have been put aboard the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Wilhelm_Gustloff_(ship)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wilhelm Gustloff (ship) (page does not exist)">Wilhelm Gustloff</a></i> which left <a href="/wiki/Gdynia" title="Gdynia">Gotenhafen (Gdynia)</a> on 30 January 1945, and was sunk by a Soviet submarine.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p><p>In August 1944, Königsberg was heavily bombed by the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Air_Force" title="Royal Air Force">Royal Air Force</a>. It suffered further extensive damage at the hands of the advancing Soviets before and after its fall on 9 April 1945. It remained thereafter under Soviet control, eventually renamed Kaliningrad. As part of a wider government campaign to obliterate all vestiges of "Prussian militarism", the remains of the castle were destroyed in 1968.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Disappearance_and_mystery">Disappearance and mystery</span></h3>
<p>The Amber Room was never seen in public again, though reports have occasionally surfaced stating that components of the Amber Room survived the war. Indeed, two elements of the room's decoration (but not the amber panels themselves) were eventually rediscovered (see below).
</p><p>There have been numerous conflicting reports and theories, among them that the Amber Room was destroyed by bombing, hidden in a now-lost subterranean bunker in Königsberg, buried in mines in the <a href="/wiki/Ore_Mountains" title="Ore Mountains">Ore Mountains</a>, or taken onto a ship or <a href="/wiki/Submarine" title="Submarine">submarine</a> which was sunk by Soviet forces in the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a>.
</p><p>Many different persons and groups, including a number of different entities from the government of the Soviet Union, have mounted extensive searches for it at various times since the war, without any success. At one point in 1998, two separate teams (one in Germany, the other in <a href="/wiki/Lithuania" title="Lithuania">Lithuania</a>) announced that they had located the Amber Room, the first in a silver mine, the second buried in a <a href="/wiki/Lagoon" title="Lagoon">lagoon</a>; neither produced the Amber Room.<sup id="cite_ref-ScotlandSunday2006_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ScotlandSunday2006-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>However, in 1997 one Italian stone mosaic that was part of a set of four which had decorated the Amber Room did turn up in western <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a>, in the possession of the family of a soldier who had helped pack up the Amber Room.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Destruction_theory">Destruction theory</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ts%C3%A1rskoye_Sel%C3%B3_-_Amber_Room.jpg" title="File:Tsárskoye Seló - Amber Room.jpg">File:Tsárskoye Seló - Amber Room.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Reconstructed amber room detail</div></div></div>
<p>Recently, British <a href="/wiki/Investigative_journalist" title="Investigative journalist" class="mw-redirect">investigative journalists</a> Catherine Scott-Clark and Adrian Levy conducted lengthy research on the fate of the Amber Room, including extensive archival research in Russia. In 2004 their book, <i>The Amber Room: The Fate of the World's Greatest Lost Treasure</i>, concluded that the Amber Room was most likely destroyed when <a href="/w/index.php?title=Battle_of_K%C3%B6nigsberg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Battle of Königsberg (page does not exist)">Königsberg Castle was burned down</a>, shortly after Königsberg surrendered to occupying Soviet forces.<sup id="cite_ref-ScotlandSunday2006_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ScotlandSunday2006-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>Documents from the archives showed that that was also the conclusion of the report of Alexander Brusov, chief of the first formal mission sent by the Soviet government to find the Amber Room, who wrote in June, 1945: "Summarizing all the facts, we can say that the Amber Room was destroyed between 9 and 11 April 1945".<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> These dates correspond with the end of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Battle_of_K%C3%B6nigsberg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Battle of Königsberg (page does not exist)">Battle of Königsberg</a> which concluded on 9 April with the surrender of the German garrison. Some years later, Brusov gave a contrary opinion; the book authors insinuate that this change of opinion was likely due to pressure from other Soviet officials, who did not want to be seen as responsible for the loss of the Amber Room.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p><p>Among other information from the archives was the revelation that the remains of the rest of the set of Italian stone mosaics were found in the burned debris of the castle.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> The authors' reasoning as to why the Soviets conducted extensive searches for the Amber Room in the years after World War II, even though their own experts had concluded that it was destroyed, is that it served the differing motives of several elements in the Soviet government: some wished to obscure (even from other branches of the Soviet government) the fact that Soviet soldiers may have been responsible for its destruction; others found the theft of the Amber Room a useful <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> <a href="/wiki/Propaganda" title="Propaganda">propaganda</a> tool, and did not want to let go of a grievance that could be aired advantageously; still others did not want to share the blame for its destruction (through their failure to evacuate the Amber Room to safety at the start of the war).<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p><p>Russian officials have denied the book's conclusions - angrily, in some cases. According to Adelaida Yolkina, senior researcher at the Pavlovsk Museum Estate: "It is impossible to see the Red Army being so careless that they let the Amber Room be destroyed." Other Russian experts were less sceptical, and had a different emphasis in their responses. Mikhail Piotrovsky, director of the State <a href="/wiki/Hermitage_Museum" title="Hermitage Museum">Hermitage Museum</a>, was very cautious in his comments, and said: "Most importantly, the destruction of the Amber Room during the Second World War is the fault of the people who started the war". In reply, Catherine Scott-Clark, one of the authors, indicated that they only came to their conclusions with reluctance: "when we started working on this issue we were hoping to be able to find the Amber Room."<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the book came out, a Russian veteran has given an interview in which he confirmed their basic conclusion as to the fate of the Amber Room, although he denies that the fires were deliberate. "I probably was one of the last people who saw the Amber Room", said Leonid Arinshtein, a literature expert with the nongovernmental Russian Culture Foundation, who was a Red Army lieutenant in charge of a rifle platoon in Königsberg in 1945. "The Red Army didn't burn anything", he said.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p><p>A variation of this theory is common currency amongst present-day residents of Kaliningrad. This is that at least part of the room was found in the cellars after World War II by the Red Army, in relatively good condition. This was not admitted at the time, in order that blame should continue to rest upon the Germans. To preserve this story, access to the ruins of the castle, which were substantial after WWII, was restricted, even to historical/archaeological surveys. During the 1960s, access to the site was suddenly withheld and the ruins were blown up by the Army in 1968, sealing any access to the underground area. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dom_Sovyetov_of_Kaliningrad&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dom Sovyetov of Kaliningrad (page does not exist)">Dom Sovetov</a> was built over the central area. The remains of the room may still be underground. It is presumed that this is what has happened and that the Russian authorities, even after the fall of Communism, have been unwilling to admit this.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Reconstructions">Reconstructions</span></h3>
<ul>
<li>In <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kleinmachnow&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kleinmachnow (page does not exist)">Kleinmachnow</a>, near Berlin, there is a miniature Amber Room, fabricated after the original. The Berlin miniature collector <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ulla_Klingbeil&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ulla Klingbeil (page does not exist)">Ulla Klingbeil</a> had this copy made of original <a href="/wiki/East_Prussia" title="East Prussia">East Prussian</a> amber. The exhibit fee at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Europarc_Dreilinden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Europarc Dreilinden (page does not exist)">Europarc Dreilinden</a> is donated to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Arilex-Verein_Foundation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arilex-Verein Foundation (page does not exist)">Arilex-Verein Foundation</a> to aid handicapped children.
</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>In 1979 a reconstruction effort began at <a href="/wiki/Tsarskoye_Selo" title="Tsarskoye Selo">Tsarskoye Selo</a>, based largely on black and white photographs of the original Amber Room. Financial difficulties to the project were solved with USD $3.5 million donated by the <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">German</a> company <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ruhrgas_AG&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ruhrgas AG (page does not exist)">Ruhrgas AG</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> By 2003, the titanic work of the Russian craftsmen was mostly completed. The new room was dedicated by Russian President <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a> and German Chancellor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gerhard_Schr%C3%B6der&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gerhard Schröder (page does not exist)">Gerhard Schröder</a> at the 300-year anniversary of the city of Saint Petersburg.
</li>
</ul>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional">
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Bernsteinzimmer01.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Bernsteinzimmer05.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Bernsteinzimmer06.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Bernsteinzimmer03.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Amberroomdetail.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Detail of the reconstructed Amber Room
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Amber Room Reconstruction-Workshop.JPG</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Reconstruction-workshop of the Amber Room
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Appearances_in_fiction">Appearances in fiction</span></h2>
<p>The mystery of the Amber Room has been the basis for the plot of several films, books and art exhibitions.
</p>
<ul>
<li> <i>The Amber Room</i>, novel by H D Evans (<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780957122000" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 9780957122000</a>)
</li>
<li> <i>The Amber Room</i>, novel by <a href="/w/index.php?title=T._Davis_Bunn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="T. Davis Bunn (page does not exist)">T. Davis Bunn</a> (<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1556612850" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1556612850</a>)
</li>
<li> <i>The Kestrel Strategy</i>, novel by C B Leonard <a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://www.thekestrelstrategy.com/">http://www.thekestrelstrategy.com/</a> (ISBN 978129111346)                       
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tatiana_(novel)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tatiana (novel) (page does not exist)">Tatiana</a></i>, novel by <a href="/wiki/Martin_Cruz_Smith" title="Martin Cruz Smith">Martin Cruz Smith</a> (<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781849838108" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 9781849838108</a>)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Amber_Room_(novel)" title="The Amber Room (novel)">The Amber Room</a></i>, novel by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Steve_Berry_(novelist)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Steve Berry (novelist) (page does not exist)">Steve Berry</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.isfdb.org/cgi-bin/pl.cgi?FSFAUG95"><i>The Amber Room</i></a>, novelette by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ian_Watson_(author)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ian Watson (author) (page does not exist)">Ian Watson</a>
</li>
<li> <i>Death in Amber</i>, novel by Dean Fetzer (<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0956158102" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0956158102</a>)
</li>
<li> <i>Amber Beach</i>, by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elizabeth_Lowell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elizabeth Lowell (page does not exist)">Elizabeth Lowell</a>
</li>
<li> <i>The Amber Secret</i>, novel by Peter Slaney
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Black_Sun_(James_Twining)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Black Sun (James Twining) (page does not exist)">The Black Sun</a></i>, by <a href="/w/index.php?title=James_Twining&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="James Twining (page does not exist)">James Twining</a>
</li>
<li> <i>The Devil Dances for Gold</i>, by Regina Ross
</li>
<li> <i>Mosaic</i>, by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gayle_Lynds&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gayle Lynds (page does not exist)">Gayle Lynds</a>
</li>
<li> <i>Cold Hit</i>, by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Linda_Fairstein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Linda Fairstein (page does not exist)">Linda Fairstein</a> (<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0671019554" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0671019554</a>)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_39_Clues&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The 39 Clues (page does not exist)">The 39 Clues</a>: <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Black_Circle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Black Circle (page does not exist)">The Black Circle</a></i>, by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Patrick_Carman&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Patrick Carman (page does not exist)">Patrick Carman</a>
</li>
<li> <i>El salón de ámbar</i>, by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Matilde_Asensi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Matilde Asensi (page does not exist)">Matilde Asensi</a>
</li>
<li> <i>The Brutal Telling</i>, by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Louise_Penny&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Louise Penny (page does not exist)">Louise Penny</a>
</li>
<li> The USA Network television series, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=White_Collar_(TV_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="White Collar (TV series) (page does not exist)">White Collar</a></i>, refers to the Amber Room extensively, especially in episode 1x08, "Hard Sell". It is revealed to one of the series' protagonists, Neal Caffrey, that his nemesis, "The Man With The Ring", and his former lover, Kate Moreau, want an amber music box that is supposedly a remnant of the room.  The alleged reason is that the box, while not overly valuable in its own right, contains some kind of secret information. Caffrey is assumed to have stolen the music box (he did not actually do so), and must locate the box in order to free Kate from "The Man With the Ring".
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Uncharted_(comics)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Uncharted (comics) (page does not exist)">Uncharted</a></i> comic book from <a href="/wiki/DC_Comics" title="DC Comics">DC Comics</a> based on the video game <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Uncharted&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Uncharted (page does not exist)">Uncharted</a></i>
</li>
<li> <i>The Red Moth</i>, by Sam Eastland
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<ul>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=%C5%A0t%C4%9Bchovice_Treasure&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Štěchovice Treasure (page does not exist)">Štěchovice Treasure</a></i> (believed by some to contain the room)
</li>
</ul>

<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sister&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sister (page does not exist)">Template:Sister</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.panoramas.classic-ru.org/museum/ekat.html">Amber Room 3D pano with high-resolution pictures of decor elements and function drag and zoom </a> by Classic studio
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.ib.hu-berlin.de/~pbruhn/bernzim.htm">Bibliographical Database of the International literature about the Amber Room</a> by Peter Bruhn
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.guide-guru.com/amber_room.htm">Amber Room Recreation - Recollection of an Eye-witness</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.amberroom.org">AmberRoom.Org: History, Photographs and Research</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://tarotcanada.tripod.com/TheAmberRoom.html">The Amber Room: Tears of the Gods</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.fatemag.com/2005_06art3.html">Mysteries of the Lost Amber Room</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/143364.stm">On the Trail of The Amber Room</a> - BBC, August 1, 1998
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3025833.stm">Peter the Great's amber room reborn</a> - BBC, 14 May 2003
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/3738593.stm">New theory on Russian art riddle</a> BBC, 24 May 2004
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://marketplace.publicradio.org/display/web/2008/02/21/german_amber_room">What to do with a German treasure</a> - APM Market Place 21 Feb, 2008
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.sptimes.ru/index.php?action_id=2&amp;story_id=751">Outrage At Amber Room Book</a> Saint Petersburg Times
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://msnbc.msn.com/id/5174876">Mystery of the Amber Room resurfaces</a> MSNBC
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.tzar.ru/a-r/1st/">The Amber Room on the Web</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.henryhatt.de/">Henry Hatt</a> - German Amber Room Investigator
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.kunstraubforschung.de/">KAKTUS e. V.</a> - Lost Art and Amber Room Research Group
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/popup?id=4189526">Photos Of Amber Room Good Morning America</a>
</li>

</li>
</ul>

<div class="portal" role="navigation" id='p-tb' aria-labelledby='p-tb-label'>
	<h3 id='p-tb-label'>Tools</h3>
	<div class="body">
